title: When the nushell repo is located in a path that has a space in it, these tests break, this fixes it
body: These 3 tests have always been broken for me since I have nushell in a path that has a space in it. Ideally, I could modify the `nu!` macro to just be able to always wrap test paths in quotes, but the way it is laid out, it will require changing the way all of the `nu!` invocations are done (probably splitting up the `path` input parameter such that it doesn't have any additional information tacked onto the end of it, so that `nu!` can be modified to wrap `cwd + path` in quotes), which may take some time. For now, this is a quick fix for these tests specifically. Before changes: After changes: With the maintainers permission, I wouldn't mind trying to look into modifying `nu!` so that it always wraps test paths in quote, so that when someone writes a test, they don't have to manually do it. EDIT: Actually, the more I look at it, it may not be possible to add a single fix into `nu!` to address all the tests, so it might have to just be updated per-test, as they come along.

title: Per directory env-variables
body:
For #86

Environment variables are added if you have created a file called .nu inside a whitelisted directory, formatted as shown below.
```
[env]
var = "value"
anothervar = "anothervalue"
```

In order for a .nu-file to be read, the directory it is in must be listed in the `nu_env_dirs` variable in nushell's `config.toml`.
```
nu_env_dirs = ["/home/sam", "/home/sam/github", "/home/sam/github/test"]
```
This was implemented for the sake of security. I do not believe that it is appropriate for nushell to pick up random .nu-files unless the user has given explicit permission. An adversary could hide a .nu-file in an otherwise unsuspicious folder that you download, and now you suddenly have nushell picking up whatever environment variables they want.
This meant that the code became more involved than just looking for a .nu-file in the current directory and applying its variables, but some of this extra code would have been needed for other features anyway.

Behavior:
- If you are in a directory, or a subdirectory to a directory with a .nu-file, the vars in that .nu-file are applied.
- If you leave a directory which set some variables, the variables are unset.
- If a directory contains a .nu with an environment variable that was already set, the old value will be overwritten. This holds even if the old value was set by a .nu in a parent directory. The overwritten value is restored when you leave the directory.

Things to do before merge:
- Write tests, do manual tests.
- Think about performance an extra time, since this code is run quite often.
- Async?
- Listen to feedback and opinions
- Sleep
- Fix clippy issues

All thoughts and suggestions welcome! Is the described behavior what you would expect?

title: Simplify plugin directory scanning
body:
This PR simplifies how we scan directories for plugins on startup.

Previous, we would scan all directories in the PATH for any file that matches `nu_plugin_*` and then attempt to load it. If we could run the exe, and get a correct configuration out of it, we added it to the list of commands. This scanning is very friendly for extending Nu, but it can be costly to scan the whole PATH for executables.

In this PR we only scan two sources: the path the "nu.exe" lives in and any additional directories the user specifies in the "plugin_dirs" config variable.

title: Str plugin promoted to built-in Nu command.
body:
`str` is now built-in. Additionally, `str` now supports optionally multiple column paths. It can either operate on raw values or tables (given column's are supplied).

`open Cargo.toml | str upcase package.name package.version`

title: Allow echo to iterate ranges
body:
This allows `echo` to iterate a range, much the same way it iterates a list now:

```
> echo 1..3
───┬───
 0 │ 1 
 1 │ 2 
 2 │ 3 
───┴───
```

title: Simplify parse plugin code.
body:
Primarily, instead of building a parse pattern enum, we just build the regex directly, with the appropriate capture group names so that the column name codepaths can be shared between simple and `--regex` patterns.

Also removed capture group count compared to column name count. I don't think this codepath can possibly be reached with the regex we now use for the simplified capture form.

(will comment more on these in place)

title: Make it-expansion work when in a list
body:
Previously, you weren't able to it-expand when the $it variable was in a list

```
> ls | echo [$it.name "bob"]
```

With this PR, that is now possible

title: Fix clippy warnings and split Scope
body:
This optimizes how we handle scope with processing many rows.  A canonical example:

```
> ls **/* | where name =~ thirdparty
```

Commands like `where` are very sensitive to the cost of clones in the case above, since each clone itself clones 2 indexmaps and 1 Value.

With this fix, on my machine we're 40% faster for 84k rows.

Let me know if this needs any additional work, I'll be happy to add to it.

title: Improve the simplified parse form.
body:
Closes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1857

Three things happening here:

First, and foremost, fully escape all special regex characters in plain text. We previously just escaped parentheses, but we should escape everything now (there's --regex)

Second, we default to lazy captures instead of greedy. This seems like the better default, with https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1857 a good example of why.

Finally, allow use of `{{` as a way to express a single `{` in simple mode.

title: Add completion for binaries on PATH
body:
This PR adds completion for executables found on the user's PATH, just like how built-in commands such as `ls` and `version` are currently completed.

The `no_bin_complete` config option can be set to `$true` to disable this behaviour.

This also alters the behaviour of where certain autocompletion options are available, making commands and executables only appear as autocompletion options when the user is typing a command, and not when they are typing its arguments. For example, `echo ver<tab>` used to complete to `echo version` because of the existence of the `version` command, which isn't ideal; this kind of completion no longer occurs.

title: Add `--regex` flag to `parse`
body:
Close #1831.

Not in this PR:
- proper escaping of patterns when `--regex` flag is not given

Things I'm not very happy about:

- `ColumnNames` is a nice abstraction for getting names both from `&[ParseCommand]` (by default) and `&Regex` (with `--regex`), but using `.0` everywhere is subpar
- `self.regex = Regex::new` lines are duplicated, because by default `self.column_names` are created before `self.regex`, and the other way around in case of `--regex`.

<details>
<summary>Testing logs</summary>

```
C:\Users\brigh\nushell(master)> git log --oneline | keep 2 | parse -r '(?P<hash>\w+) (?P<message>.+)'
───┬──────────┬──────────────────────────────────────────
 # │ hash     │ message 
───┼──────────┼──────────────────────────────────────────
 0 │ ae87582c │ Fix missing invocation errors (#1846)
 1 │ b89976da │ let format access variables also (#1842)
───┴──────────┴──────────────────────────────────────────

C:\Users\brigh\nushell(master)> git log --oneline | keep 2 | parse -r '(\w+) (?P<message>.+)'
───┬──────────┬──────────────────────────────────────────
 # │ Capture1 │ message
───┼──────────┼──────────────────────────────────────────
 0 │ ae87582c │ Fix missing invocation errors (#1846)
 1 │ b89976da │ let format access variables also (#1842)
───┴──────────┴──────────────────────────────────────────

C:\Users\brigh\nushell(master)> git log --oneline | keep 2 | parse -r '(?P<hash>\w+) (.+)'
───┬──────────┬──────────────────────────────────────────
 # │ hash     │ Capture2
───┼──────────┼──────────────────────────────────────────
 0 │ ae87582c │ Fix missing invocation errors (#1846)
 1 │ b89976da │ let format access variables also (#1842)
───┴──────────┴──────────────────────────────────────────
```

</details>

title: Fix completer handling of paths with spaces
body:
Closes #1850.

This uses the `lite_parse` components of `nu_parser` to perform a more accurate parsing of arguments for completions, which means that it gets the correct start position for paths in quotes containing spaces.

If the parser fails here for some reason, it will fall back to the old "look for the closest space" algorithm to determine the completion start point.

title: Update minimum Rust version requirement in README
body:
Commit a4c1b092baa86bb9c113ed3d85a96236a00eeb49 introduced uses of `map_or` on `Result`, which was [only stabilised in Rust 1.41](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/src/core/result.rs.html#545).

Trying to build nushell on earlier versions of Rust fails:

```rust
error[E0599]: no method named `map_or` found for type `std::result::Result<std::string::String, nu_errors::ShellError>` in the current scope
   --> crates/nu-cli/src/format/table.rs:322:18
    |
322 |                 .map_or(Alignment::LEFT, |a| match a.to_lowercase().as_str() {
    |                  ^^^^^^ help: there is a method with a similar name: `map_err`

error[E0599]: no method named `map_or` found for type `std::result::Result<std::string::String, nu_errors::ShellError>` in the current scope
   --> crates/nu-cli/src/format/table.rs:330:27
    |
330 |             c.as_string().map_or(color::GREEN, |c| {
    |                           ^^^^^^ help: there is a method with a similar name: `map_err`

error[E0599]: no method named `map_or` found for type `std::result::Result<std::string::String, nu_errors::ShellError>` in the current scope
   --> crates/nu-cli/src/format/table.rs:342:26
    |
342 |                         .map_or(Attr::Bold, |s| str_to_style(s).unwrap_or(Attr::Bold))],
    |                          ^^^^^^ help: there is a method with a similar name: `map_err`

error: aborting due to 3 previous errors

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0599`.
error: failed to compile `nu v0.14.0 (/home/aaron/.cache/yay/nushell-stable/src/nushell-0.14.0)`, intermediate artifacts can be found at `/home/aaron/.cache/yay/nushell-stable/src/nushell-0.14.0/target`

Caused by:
  could not compile `nu-cli`.
```

This PR updates the README to reflect this new minimum version requirement.

title: String interpolation
body:
This adds a simple templating string interpolation to Nu. Templates are filled in with the shorthand column-path (which `where` also uses).

Backticks surround a string interpolation, and from there a handlebars/mustache style template escape lets you add in a shorthand path:

```
> ls | echo `{{name}} is of size {{size}}`
```

Since it's a shorthand path, you can also use the longhand paths to reach other variables

```
> echo `my temp-dir is {{$nu.temp-dir}}`
my temp-dir is /tmp
```

Yes, it's also possible to get fancy.

```
> echo `my host is {{$(sys).host.name}}`
my host is Linux
```

title: default history size to 100k
body:
100k is ultimately an arbitrary number. This now raises the question of, do we need history size to be configurable at all?

https://github.com/fish-shell/fish-shell/issues/2674#issuecomment-171198612

> but the short answer is that fish uses a LRU list to manage history, that it's limited to 256k unique items, and that there's no configuration knob to control this

body: This allows you to do a bit more with the format command. With it, you'll now be able to access variables and evaluate a full column path.

title: Fix broken ordering of args when parsing command with env vars.
body:
Fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1795

`swap_remove` removes the element by swapping it with the last item. This means the ordering of arguments change, which can be detrimental to a command which cares about this ordering.

Closes #1829 

A few questions I have:

1. Where would tests for this live? Should this be tested?
2. Is casting to `usize` acceptable? I see it is done [here](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/5f1136dcb07ef1c1a6adabe5ea332dcfd40a1301/crates/nu-cli/src/cli.rs#L576).

title: Remove interpretation of `Primitive::Nothing` as the number 0.
body:
Closes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1833
Fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1783

`Nothing` should be regarded as an "absence of value". Use of it in any mathematical context should be regarded as an error, which we should propagate upwards. This PR doesn't deal with propagating errors, but does prevent it from behaving like zero in some contexts.

body: completes #1826

title: Issue 1787
body:
Fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1603

> When piping a row into the sum command, nushell panics.

Rows are now summed when piped to the `sum` command. As it currently stands, nu reports an error if the user attempts to sum a table in which one of the cells contains another table so this: 
```
sys | sum
```
gives the following error:
```
error: Attempted to compute the sum of a value that cannot be summed.
- shell:1:9
1 | sys | sum
  | ^^^ value appears here
```
since `sys` outputs a table whose cells contain a table. While the following command: 
```
cal | sum
```
outputs the sum of each of the rows in the table, since each cell contains a primitive value.

title: Move from language-reporting to codespan
body:
This moves us from `language-reporting` to `codespan-reporting`. While both are useful for reporting errors, codespan has a couple advantages:

* It's maintained and actively developed for new features and improvements
* It allows for better errors as we can do things like add notes to errors
* Has better utf-8 support, so underlines should be more correct

Fixes https://github.com/nushell/nushell/issues/1127

![Screenshot from 2020-05-18 20-04-47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/547158/82194801-7c95a400-994b-11ea-8dbf-16aeb00b2a46.png)

title: Allow user to specify the indentation setting on the pretty flag for the to json command
body:
By default, the new `to json` `--pretty` flag would set the output indentation automatically to 4 spaces, but I feel that others may want another value for this, such as 2.  This PR changes the flag such that it requires an unsigned int, which allows the user to specify their preferred indentation setting.

```
> cal -ymq --month-names --full-year 2020 | where friday == 13 | to json --pretty 2
[
  {
    "year": 2020,
    "quarter": 1,
    "month": "march",
    "sunday": 8,
    "monday": 9,
    "tuesday": 10,
    "wednesday": 11,
    "thursday": 12,
    "friday": 13,
    "saturday": 14
  },
  {
    "year": 2020,
    "quarter": 4,
    "month": "november",
    "sunday": 8,
    "monday": 9,
    "tuesday": 10,
    "wednesday": 11,
    "thursday": 12,
    "friday": 13,
    "saturday": 14
  }
]
```

```
> cal -ymq --month-names --full-year 2020 | where friday == 13 | to json --pretty 4
[
    {
        "year": 2020,
        "quarter": 1,
        "month": "march",
        "sunday": 8,
        "monday": 9,
        "tuesday": 10,
        "wednesday": 11,
        "thursday": 12,
        "friday": 13,
        "saturday": 14
    },
    {
        "year": 2020,
        "quarter": 4,
        "month": "november",
        "sunday": 8,
        "monday": 9,
        "tuesday": 10,
        "wednesday": 11,
        "thursday": 12,
        "friday": 13,
        "saturday": 14
    }
]
```

title: Check capture group count
body:
Addresses first part of #1797
>Prevent the panic from ever occurring. I'd recommend checking the number of capture groups against the number of column names.

Output for the input given in that bug:
```
     Running `target/debug/nu --commands 'echo "tests.html" | parse "{filename}[.{ext}]?"'`
error: The are 2 column(s) specified: [filename, ext], but there are only 1 regex match(es): [tests.html]
- shell:1:47
1 | echo "tests.html" | parse "{filename}[.{ext}]?"
  |                           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ the number of regex matches does not equal the number of columns specified here
```

and I thought it would also be good to bound the length of the error spew
```
     Running `target/debug/nu --commands 'echo "reallylongnametests.html" | parse "{filename}[.{ext}]?"'`
error: The are 2 column(s) specified: [filename, ext], but there are only 1 regex match(es): [reallylongnametes...]
- shell:1:61
1 | echo "reallylongnametests.html" | parse "{filename}[.{ext}]?"
  |                                         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ the number of regex matches does not equal the number of columns specified here
```

I am new to Nu so looking for feedback!

title: create Palette trait
body:
As stated in #1798, we'd like to be able to support user defined color schemes. The first step in this process seems to be abstracting out the ability to style spans. In this PR, we introduce the `Pallet` trait. The only implementor at the moment is the `DefaultPallet`, however, as stated in #1798 we aim to eventually be able to define our own base16 file format and then create a Pallet that can use those files.

I'd like to actually put the Pallet code in it's own file, but I kept getting compile errors like
```
103 |     pub fn paint_string<'l, P: Pallet>(
    |                                ^^^^^^ not found in this scope
```

I think this is due to my lack of knowledge on the Rust module system. Any guidance here would be much appreciated.

Also, we should probably discuss whether or not `paint_string` should remain a static function. It's starting to take in several parameters now and it might just be worth making it a method.

title: Adds support to pretty format the json in `to json`
Remove the old it-hacks from fetch and post
body: We add some old hacks in `fetch` and `post` that prevented them from using the full it-expansion.  This PR just removes those hacks so they don't interfere with the expansion pass

title: Fix parsing of invocations with a dot
Evaluation of command arguments
body:
This PR adds the ability to evaluate an arbitrary block as part of argument evaluation.

Eg)

```
> echo $(= 1 + 4)
```
Or:

```
> echo $(sys).host.name
```

To do so, we needed to do a fairly extensive refactor of how arguments were processed.  The new system assumes that expression evaluation can be done async, in order to be able to process whole pipelines.

The amount of changes makes me suspect there will be breakages, but since we just put out a release, we should hopefully have time to calm any issues before the next release.

title: Extracted grouping by date to it's own subcommand.
added config check to disable auto pivoting of single row outputs
body: fixes #1770, resolves #1518

title: added nothing value for incalcuable dir sizes
body: fixes #1785

title: Use the directories crate instead of app_dirs
body:
The app_dirs crate is abandonned since quite a bit of time. Use the directories
crate instead, which is maintained and have more OS support.

title: doc: add rename command page
body:
Hi

This PR documents the `rename` command introduced in https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/1447

I feel like the fields of `/etc/passwd` is a nice fit for this example.

title: Allow external binary to register custom commands.
body:
This changeset contains everything that a separate binary needs to
register its own commands (including the new help function). It is
very possible that this commit misses other pub use exports, but
the contained ones work for our use cases so far.

title: doc: add more from command pages
body:
Hi

This PR add basic document pages for `from ini` and `from url` commands.

I've also added links to the url spec to clearly define the format used by `serde`: https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#application/x-www-form-urlencoded

title: Add (near) automatic testing for command examples
doc: add headers command page
body:
Hi

This PR adds a short documentation page for the `headers` command introduced in https://github.com/nushell/nushell/pull/1530

The example is taken from the blog https://www.nushell.sh/blog/2020/03/31/nushell_0_12_0.html#headers-samhedin

title: doc: rename edit command to update
body:
Hi

In the recent commit https://github.com/nushell/nushell/commit/c3efdf2689b0bea169a88e65c419045be889cd9b, `edit` was renamed to `update` but it was not yet reflected in the documentation.
